title: Effectifs policiers par circonscription / département - Une demande d'accès à l'information à Ministère de l'Intérieur

last_post.content:
À la suite de ma demande au ministère de l'intérieur en août 2021 (https://madada.fr/demande/effectifs_policiers_par_circonsc) et d'un recours devant le tribunal administratif, le ministère a mis en ligne les bilans sociaux de 2011 à 2020 (https://www.police-nationale.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/Bilan-social).
Espérons que ça devienne une habitude. J'avais également demandé le détail des effectifs de policiers et gendarmes par circonscription, mais hélas, le ministère dit ne pas disposer d'informations plus précises que la répartition par grandes régions... À suivre.

Do you speak Spanish? Are you familiar with the mathematical notions of probability and odds?Yes? Bueno, continue reading!

A question to you: How do you translate "odds"? We have used the untranslated, English term "odds" in the Spanish version of the Elements of AI (see https://course.elementsofai.com/es/3/1), but apparently this is still causing some confusion.

What we want to be clear about is the difference between probability and odds: e.g. probability 1/2 <=> odds 1:1.

title: When Will We Hit Peak Fossil Fuels? Maybe We Already Have - Inside Climate News

last_post.content:
When Will We Hit Peak Fossil Fuels? Maybe We Already Have

Some #Twitter things that the company didn’t build or invent itself:

• Twitterrific was the first mobile Twitter app

• The word tweet made its first official appearance on Twitterrific

• The hashtag was from Chris Messina

• Advanced Twitter Search was originally Summize

• Twitter bought TweetDeck

• Live stream was from Periscope acquisition

• The official Twitter app was originally Tweetie which they purchased from Loren Brichter

• Mentioning people with an @ was user driven and wasn’t linked to accounts because they didn’t consider conversations to take place on Twitter initially

• Quote tweet was adopted from people copy+pasting tweets and adding RT in front of the copied tweet

• Threads were built to accomodate existing user behavior

Did I miss anything major?

[update 29/1] lots of additions in the replies that I thought should get added here

• Image attachments added after third party services like imageshack/yfrog, and twitpic became super popular.

• Twitterrific was first to officially associate Twitter with a bird

• Retweet was adopted from user behavior (you couldn’t comment or add context using the official retweet so many people kept using RT until Twitter introduced native QT)

• Scheduling, posting across accounts, and team/shared accounts were from Hootsuite

• Popularity of short link services like isgd and bitly lead to tco url masking

Something that people may not have been aware, in my corner of Twitter in those early years, people interpreted RT not as retweet but as reply to. So they weren’t replying by hitting the reply button but by manually quote tweeting and adding RT after their response.

There’s enough confusion over RT so I’m gonna add this example

title: Marie Tharp pioneered mapping the bottom of the ocean 6 decades ago – scientists are still learning about Earth's last frontier

last_post.content:
Pioneering geologist & oceanographer Marie Tharp changed our understanding of the ocean.

When Tharp sought a geology job at Columbia University in 1948, women couldn’t go on research ships. Instead, she was hired to assist male grad students.

Back then, many scientists still assumed the bottom of the ocean was featureless. Tharp figured out how to use data to create sketches of the ocean floor. Her hand-drawn maps helped develop plate tectonic theory. https://theconversation.com/marie-tharp-pioneered-mapping-the-bottom-of-the-ocean-6-decades-ago-scientists-are-still-learning-about-earths-last-frontier-142451 #science #history

@colinsmatt11 @freemo @JensHannemann Thanks! I think FEP-c390: Identity Proofs is more relevant to this discussion, because with it we can add a decentralized identity layer to the Fediverse. If two actors have identity proofs signed by the same key, this means these actors are controlled by the same person.

FEP-8b32 is concerned with signing activities/objects, it's an alternative to HTTP signatures.

title: OpenAI, Microsoft want court to toss lawsuit accusing them of abusing open-source code

last_post.content:
The lead attorney for GitHub arguing that #Copilot using #OpenSource is fair use following precedent from #Oracle Vs #Google is Annette Hurst, who represented Oracle and personally argued against the verdict in public on Twitter.
https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/openai-microsoft-want-court-toss-lawsuit-accusing-them-abusing-open-source-code-2023-01-27/

So I buy this argument overall: https://mastodon.social/@matthewskelton/109769120406420713

However I think there’s a useful concept we shouldn’t lose. While it’s not true that commons default to dead because of misuse, I think it’s fair to say digital commons may behave differently. The key is a lack of defined community or social consequences or no ways to mutually observe commons health. Not to say this can’t exist. But if it doesn’t, commons are legitimately hard to keep healthy.
